subject: RE: [junit] Re: Test Grouping/Partitioning
msgSnippet: ... Good questions.  I d give you my own answers, but I doubt they are too interesting to this group, and they re definitely far off topic of the conversation
messageBody:
> That's not quite what I'm thinking, but it's closer.
> Certainly, I'd be shocked to see 14 hours of fast tests, but
> even 14 hours of slow tests on a single project is out of the
> ordinary. I can't envision a single project that big. I'd
> want to ask the people on that project two questions:
>
> 1. Why such reliance on slow tests?
> 2. Should we break this up into about four subprojects?

Good questions. I'd give you my own answers, but I doubt
they are too interesting to this group, and they're definitely
far off topic of the conversation about how to group tests
together.

> Is it really a good idea to have a test suite so long that
> you can't run it overnight between when people leave for work
> and when they come back in the morning? How do you do a daily build?

We have several test suites. The unit tests run every night
and give one level of confidence. And then some system test
suites run each night to give more confidence about different
things each night. In total, it takes 2 nights, but there is
usable feedback each night.

> No question there. If you've managed to reduce the feedback
> cycle from 6 weeks to 2 days, then that's great work. Still,
> I find a 2-day cycle quite long. I imagine you have bigger
> problems to face right now, so you're right to face them and
> not this one, but all things being equal, I wouldn't be
> satisfied with a 2-day cycle, and I certainly wouldn't design
> JUnit to optimize for the case of the 2-day test cycle.

Yes, that's one reason I don't think my own stories are
overly relevant. I'm not in the "sweet spot" of users
of JUnit, as I'm using it for both unit tests and for
system tests. And, while I know there are other people
in my same boat, we're in the minority.

> But that's great work. I'm impressed. Have you written about
> what you do differently between the 6-week cycle and the
> 2-day cycle?

Only on my resume. :-)


Todd.
